title: Politics 204 for September 3 - Winnipeg Free Press
text:
Quote: of the Day Immigration Minister Chris Alexander answers a question during question period in the House of Commons. “The tragic photo of young Aylan Kurdi and the news of the death of his brother and mother broke hearts around the world. I am meeting with officials to ascertain both the facts of the case of the Kurdi family and to receive an update on the migrant crisis." -- Federal Immigration Minister Chris Alexander in a statement given in response to growing concerns about Canada’s response to the refugee crisis. A tragedy that derails the election A paramilitary police officer investigates the scene before lifting from the sea shore the body of a migrant child near Bodrum, Turkey, on Wednesday. A change of heart?: The impact of a photograph of a three-year-old boy whose body washed up on a beach in Turkey derailed the election campaign today. Prime Minister Stephen Harper changed his campaign and didn’t make a planned infrastructure announcement in Vancouver. His Defence Minister Jason Kenney also cancelled a planned announcement on a security-related immigration issue. Meanwhile: Immigration Minister Chris Alexander said he was “suspending” his campaign and flew to Ottawa to deal with news the family of the boy had been seeking asylum in Canada but had been rejected. The government now denies the application was actually turned down. Alexander was criticized Wednesday for accusing the media of ignoring the Syrian refugee crisis instead of addressing the government’s role in the matter. "This could be our Cecil the Lion”: The death of three-year-old Aylan Kurdi has galvanized Canadians into action on the refugee crisis in Europe. Local immigration lawyers and refugee rights activists are condemning the Harper government for its current policy towards refugees across the world. Tom Denton, the executive director of Hospitality House Refugee Ministry here in Winnipeg, says the government needs to stop treating refugees as immigrants trying to enter Canada, and instead as people in a crisis situation in need of rescue. Meanwhile in Manitoba École J.B. Mitchell School’s Global Kidizens Group. Top salaries for low marks: Manitoba teachers earn amongst the highest salaries and richest pensions in Canada, while the province’s students rank almost dead last in academic assessments. It’s time to bring them in line with other provinces, and a CD Howe study suggests that can start by moving to central bargaining as do all other provinces. Key of Bart: Conservative leader Stephen Harper sees nothing but blue skies when it comes to Canada's economy. The perfect fodder for our latest Key of Bart. With apologies to Irving Berlin and federal election junkies everywhere. In case you missed it Justice Murray Sinclair Historic vote: Sheila North Wilson is the first woman Grand Chief of MKO. Honouring Sinclair: The University of Winnipeg has awarded Justice Murray Sinclair the 2015 Duff Roblin Award presented to a Manitoban with a profound dedication to education and community. Not so innovative: Manitoba receives a failing grade from the Conference Board of Canada in terms of innovation. Other voices Trying to come here: The family of child found dead on Turkish beach were trying to come to Canada. The Ottawa citizen’s story. Going back: Abdullah Kurdi, the father of the little boy who’s dead body has become the symbol of the Syrian refugee crisis, says he’s going back to bury his son in his home town of Kobani. In the Guardian. Our moral crisis: Today’s editorial in the Globe and Mail Today in history In 1992, then prime minister Brian Mulroney announced a referendum will be held October 26th on the Charlottetown accord. It didn’t pass. The Free Press Politics: 204 is published weekday afternoons.
